title: 109_hr1372
content: The "Quality Nursing Care Act of 2005" may be cited as such. The Congress finds that hospitals in the US have inadequate staffing of registered nurses, which directly impacts patient health. There is a critical shortage of registered nurses leading to unsafe staffing levels, compromising patient safety and creating a public health crisis. Registered nurses are working under conditions that do not support quality healthcare or a healthy work environment. The Federal Government has a compelling interest in promoting the safety of individuals entitled to benefits under the Medicare program by requiring hospitals to establish minimum safe staffing levels for registered nurses. Establishment of minimum staffing ratios by Medicare participating hospitals. Medicare participating hospitals must adopt and implement a staffing system that meets specific requirements, including records maintenance, data collection, and data submission. Medicare participating hospitals must adopt a staffing system that meets requirements for records maintenance, data collection, and data submission to comply with non-discrimination and retaliation regulations under Title XVIII of the Social Security Act. "Staffing requirements for Medicare participating hospitals include record maintenance, data collection, and submission to comply with regulations under Title XVIII of the Social Security Act." Each participating hospital must establish a staffing system ensuring appropriate levels of registered nurses on each shift and unit based on patient numbers and care intensity. Input from direct care-giving nurses or their representatives is required, accounting for contextual staffing issues. The staffing system in hospitals should consider contextual issues, staff experience, recommended levels by nursing organizations, and adjustable nurse-to-patient ratios based on patient acuity. Registered nurses should not be assigned excessive workloads. The staffing system in hospitals should ensure that registered nurses are qualified to provide care in specific units and be based on methods that assure validity and reliability. The system should not set nurse levels below legal requirements or use minimum nurse-to-patient ratios as upper limits on staffing. Participating hospitals must post daily staffing information for each shift. The hospital must post daily nursing staff information for each shift, make it available to the public upon request, and submit staffing system details to the Secretary. The hospital must submit nursing staff information electronically to the Secretary quarterly. The Secretary will make this information publicly available and audit it for accuracy. Record-keeping, data collection, and evaluation are also required. The participating hospital must maintain records for at least 3 years to determine if they have implemented a staffing system. Data collection on patient acuity and nursing-sensitive outcomes is required by the Secretary. The participating hospital must evaluate its staffing system annually to ensure reliability and validity. This includes monitoring patient outcomes like falls and infections, operational outcomes such as turnover rates and nursing care hours, and patient complaints related to staffing levels. The evaluation of the hospital's staffing system must be conducted annually to ensure reliability and validity. A joint management-staff committee, with at least 50% registered nurses, will oversee the process. The Secretary is responsible for enforcing the requirements of this section and investigating complaints against participating hospitals. The Secretary investigates complaints against participating hospitals and may impose civil money penalties of up to $10,000 for knowing violations of requirements. The Secretary may impose a penalty of more than $10,000 for violations by participating hospitals with a pattern of such violations. Procedures similar to section 1128A apply, and violations are publicly disclosed on the Department of Health and Human Services website. The Secretary may impose penalties on participating hospitals for violations, with details published on the Department of Health and Human Services website. Penalties for hospitals under previous ownership will not be disclosed after a 1-year period. Whistle-blower protections are also provided. Whistle-blower protections prohibit discrimination or retaliation against patients or employees who raise grievances related to hospital staffing. Employees facing such actions can seek judicial relief, including reinstatement and reimbursement for losses. Employees who face discrimination or retaliation for raising grievances related to hospital staffing are entitled to reinstatement, lost wages, and benefits. They can also seek reasonable attorney's fees and costs. Patients who experience discrimination or retaliation can take legal action in a District Court and may receive $5,000 in liquidated damages. Prevailing patients are also entitled to attorney's fees and costs. No action can be brought after a certain limitation period. Employees facing discrimination or retaliation for raising grievances related to hospital staffing are entitled to reinstatement, lost wages, benefits, and attorney's fees. Patients experiencing discrimination or retaliation can take legal action in District Court and may receive $5,000 in liquidated damages. No action can be brought more than 2 years after the discrimination or retaliation occurred. An adverse employment action is considered retaliation or discrimination and includes failure to promote or provide eligible benefits, adverse evaluations, and decisions related to accreditation, certification, credentialing, or licensing. The section discusses rules of construction related to certification, credentialing, or licensing of individuals and adverse personnel actions. It clarifies that the section does not exempt individuals from liability under state laws or permit conduct prohibited under the National Labor Relations Act. The Secretary will promulgate regulations to implement the Act, and definitions for terms like 'participating hospital' and 'registered nurse' are provided. The amendments made by this section will become effective on January 1, 2006, defining terms like 'shift' and 'person' in the context of hospital units and scheduling.
